newsitem.title: USA: Citrix shares surge after Microsoft agrees to license.
newsitem.headline: Citrix shares surge after Microsoft agrees to license.

text.p: Citrix Systems Inc. shares surged Monday after Microsoft Corp. agreed to license its software technology and include it in upcoming versions of Microsoft Windows NT.

As part of the agreement, Citrix, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., will get an initial $75 million fee from Microsoft and as much as $100 million in royalties tied to sales of Microsoft products using Citrix technology, the companies said.
Citrix's stock jumped $13.25 to $32.50 in afternoon trading on Nasdaq where it was the most active issue.

The agreement erased much of the concern in recent months about Citrix. In February, Citrix's stock plunged after Microsoft told Citrix executives that if the companies could not agree to develop the technology together, Microsoft would go it alone.

Citrix writes software that lets an outdated terminal -- a type of computer that gets its computing horsepower from a mainframe computer or a corporate network -- run programmes written for Microsoft's Windows.

Microsoft agreed to add the technology to the current version of its Windows NT 4.0 operating system. The world's biggest PC software company also will build the next version of Windows NT around the technology.
In recent months, Microsoft, after initially ridiculing the idea, has taken the idea of network computers seriously as business customers clamour for cheaper and easier-to-use computers.
The company now is working to make cheap terminals capable of running business software.
Microsoft also said Monday it agreed to license technology from France's Prologue Software SA, another company that writes terminal software.
Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., owns a 6 percent stake in Citrix. Microsoft's treasurer, Greg Maffei, also sits on Citrix's board.
